3.42.text: It's a pleasure to be here.

8.55.text:
I can still remember the impending doom that
I felt in my courtroom.

15.28.text:
Everybody was looking at me with condemnation,
and rightfully so.

17.66.text:
I was guilty, although I adamantly denied
that.

23.23.text:
The judge slammed his gavel down and looked
at me over his glasses and said:

28.03.text:
"Mr. Kelly, a jury of your peers has found
you guilty of the crime of murder and has

36.79.text: sentenced you to life in a state penitentiary.

41.77.text: Now, do you have anything to say for yourself?"

53.34.text:
I stood there trembling, awash in the devastation
that I had caused and of the devastation that

60.68.text: I knew was coming for me.

66.96.text: I couldn't clean up that mess.

68.48.text: I was still in my mess.

69.93.text: I didn't know how to get out of it.

78.80.text:
Since then my life has been a surreal journey
of shame, guilt, prison, but remarkably also

89.39.text: of self-discovery and redemption, and service.

95.95.text:
I am not the same man I was 24 years ago when
I so recklessly took a life in a dope deal

105.59.text:
It's something I regret every single day,
but who of us is the same person we were 24

118.25.text:
I'm going to tell you something enlightening
about prison.

129.69.text:
It's “One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest”
meets “Shawshank Redemption”.

134.84.text:
I'd give you more up to date analogies, but
we watch way too many reruns in the big house.

141.59.text:
Here's what I want you to know about the people
that are in prison and about me and my case.

151.68.text:
Hurting people hurt people, usually themselves
in the form of poor choices or addiction or

164.03.text:
I have spoken with literally hundreds of murderers
and violent offenders, and that truth runs

172.98.text: So I just wanted you to know about that.

176.62.text:
I want to share with you a little bit about
my prison experience.

180.22.text:
I remember my “welcome to prison” moment
when I went down and they put me on a unit

193.19.text: A lot of angst in the house.

201.71.text:
We fought over benches to sit on, TV shows
to watch, whether we were going to watch Terminator

210.54.text:
We fought over food or things that resembled
it.

214.67.text: We even fought about who could fight who.

220.40.text:
You know what, if you're in prison, you better
fight or you better at least sell it to somebody

227.99.text:
In Texas prisons we have a thing that's called
the “check game”.

232.59.text:
When you come to prison, when you go to the
day room, somebody, usually several somebodys

238.04.text:
of a different race are going to approach
you and do a heart check.

242.65.text:
They want to find out if you're willing to
fight for yourself and your belongings.

246.17.text: Make no mistake, the whole day room is watching.

252.31.text:
Everybody wants to know where you're at in
the pecking order.

258.77.text: If you won't fight, it's ugly.

262.66.text:
You become property to be used, a resource
to be used and traded.

270.72.text:
I have counselled many young men who came
to prison, and I told them, "Go down to that

275.53.text:
day room and meet this head on, and you fight
like there's no tomorrow, and if you do, the

282.80.text:
members of your own race are going to back
you and they're going to make sure that you

286.13.text: don't get beat down too badly.

289.37.text: But if you don't fight, nobody else will either.

297.06.text: That is a lonely place to be in prison.

298.63.text: It's like being in the Serengeti.”

303.49.text: So I was out on the rec yard one day.

306.91.text:
I had only been there a month or two, and
I was contemplating how I even ended up in

313.75.text: I was a pretty good kid.

315.85.text: I was voted Mr. Junior High School.

321.34.text:
Homecoming king candidate, stellar athlete
in school.

325.96.text:
I went to a Division Two school on a track
scholarship.

328.85.text: I even pledged Pi Kappa Alpha.

331.36.text:
How does that guy end up in prison with a
life sentence for murder?

336.11.text: It was baffling even to me.

337.37.text: Now, sure, I came from a broken home.

341.33.text: Alcoholism runs deep in my family.

343.90.text:
I saw a little bit of abuse when I was growing
up, although it didn't deal with me.

349.71.text: That's not the makings of a murderer.

352.67.text:
So I was contemplating that on the rec yard
when a race riot broke out.

364.33.text: In an instant it was chaos on the yard.

368.61.text:
It was 70 on 20, and I was a member of the
20, and for reasons I don't even know.

378.32.text: It was fight or get hurt.

381.89.text:
So I cut a swatch through the crowd, swinging
wildly, trying to find safety, if there was

391.16.text:
Safety ended up to be a cloud of tear gas
that the officers shot in, that I was thankful

401.85.text:
For the next several hours we lay face down
on the rec yard, handcuffed with plastic pull

407.74.text: ties, and covered in fire ants.

410.70.text:
When I get to heaven, I've got a discussion
with god about the usefulness of fire ants,

414.96.text: but that's for another time and discussion.

418.93.text:
Once the guards regained control they locked
us all up in our blocks.

424.47.text: For the next 30 days we were on lock down.

426.94.text:
In your cell with your "celly" in a six foot
by nine foot cell, two bunks, and a toilet

434.96.text:
Three times a day a guard will bring you a
sack lunch, and you rarely see anybody else.

448.17.text:
So one night I was standing in front of my
cell bored, listening to the collaborative

453.24.text:
din of the cell block, and I heard the telltale
sounds of a fight.

459.95.text:
Tennis shoes squeaking, grunts and groans,
the thud of flesh on flesh, and I heard a

465.94.text: man say, "No, I'm a man too."

476.02.text: Shortly after that, the scuffling stopped.

479.54.text:
I thought, my god, that man's lock down is
way worse than mine.

485.99.text:
Do you see how hopelessness and despair and
anger grip prison?

494.26.text:
It covers it like a cloud and it just chokes
out any ideas about change or hope.

501.59.text:
If a man is going to change in prison, there
are precious few handholds and even fewer

508.65.text: hands reaching down to help pull him up.

514.04.text: I was blessed to find some of those hands.

515.55.text: I reached out for people to do that.

518.35.text: People would not let me languish in prison.

522.55.text: I had people that cared about me.

525.87.text:
I got a sponsor in AA, and we started processing
things.

530.84.text:
We started opening up and peeling back my
onion and looking at things that were going

537.21.text:
We took a fearless and thorough inventory
of my life and replaced the broken parts that

542.21.text:
have never served me well with new things,
and I grew, and my outlook changed.

548.21.text:
I got a different viewpoint, one not centered
on me.

552.21.text:
Once I started to do that I started sharing
these great truths, these jewels, with my

558.14.text: cohort, with my friends in prison.

562.88.text:
Once I pull the beam out of my own eye I can
help somebody else do the same thing.

570.33.text: And things started changing for me.

572.92.text:
What I realized along the way was something
very important.

578.92.text:
If hurting people hurt people, healing people
heal people.

586.97.text:
That's another great truth to stand on, and
I share that a lot.

592.08.text: So 22 years I did in the belly of the whale.

597.67.text:
Twelve parole denials and I finally came up
again, and made parole.

603.78.text:
I'd been granted freedom, even on a life sentence,
it was a weird sentencing quirk in Texas at

612.54.text: Thank god almighty I was free at last."

620.17.text:
It's amazing to go through the arduous trek
of prison and get out and realize that I've

626.29.text:
just entered the promised land of freedom
and there are giants and armies and battles

631.58.text:
to be fought that most of the people coming
out of prison are not prepared for.

637.29.text:
I was lucky because I had a strong network
around me, a strong group to help me out.

646.07.text:
Somewhere along the way I joined an amazing
group, a nonprofit called the Prison Entrepreneurship

653.35.text:
Innovative program that sees us not as what
we've done, but who we could be.

660.94.text:
For the first time in my life I saw something
I could really invest in, in my life and start

668.92.text: You can look this up on pep.org.

672.61.text:
PEP brings in outside business folks, people
who have been very successful, who have made

681.31.text:
money and now are willing to make a difference,
to go into prison and impact lives, and we

686.24.text:
couple them with guys on the inside who are
aspiring entrepreneurs, who want to do something

692.50.text:
different, who are committed to change, and
when we get those two people together, amazing

698.54.text:
Here's what I want you to know about the guys
in prison.

701.67.text:
From their trade on the street they know a
lot about business, they just don't know that

707.76.text:
They know things about profit margins, they
know about supply chains, they know about

714.58.text: risk management, they know about marketing.

730.44.text:
They have got hustle and they are not afraid

734.77.text:
So our founder realized that with a little

738.95.text:
apply those natural skills to those guys and
they can start a legitimate business when

744.62.text:
But look, we are not trying to make better

750.04.text: We're trying to forge better men.

751.58.text:
So we put them through a refining fire, nine
months long, with a lot of character stuff

757.90.text: It was things that I had prepared myself for.

760.28.text:
So I became an asset to that program on the
inside.

768.98.text:
I know that this crowd knows that the recidivism
rate for men and women coming out of prison

776.26.text:
It is difficult to get a job and difficult
to get started.

778.62.text:
It is difficult to do anything, but with PEP

788.17.text:
network of people that we have, the partnership

793.48.text:
Guys get out from PEP and we have a 7% recidivism

801.27.text: I got to be one of those statistics.

804.03.text:
I get to get out and just shine because of

810.75.text: We've had 1,500 graduates of our program.

Over 200 businesses started, the top six of

820.24.text:
But you know what, just the guys that get

826.37.text:
children in a positive manner, and become
a great employee because of the tool belt

831.29.text: that we've given them, that's a success too.

835.00.text:
When I got out after 22 years I had never
Googled anything, I had never sent an email,

842.67.text:
I had never used a debit card, never used
a cellphone.

846.63.text: Now I can't go anywhere without my cellphone.

851.22.text:
You know, we were talking earlier and I realized
I didn't even know how to order coffee at

858.08.text: Do you guys take a class for that or something?

863.79.text: But things had changed so much.

About a week out my case manager, PEP has

who can show the guys how to walk the walk,

he stopped to get gas, and as he was climbing

He looked at me and said, "That's kind of

I said, "Here's the deal, they didn't have

He looked at me and he got it because he has

I said, "I figured it was, but I didn't want

There are so many instances like that that

964.25.text:
The housing thing is an issue for all of our

There are so many policies out there that

I'm not pointing at you individually, but
that's how we feel and that's how the policies

995.34.text: So the guys in PEP are blessed.

The thing is, we have got solid individuals

So if healing people heal people, here's what

1013.66.text:
Some of these guys, and there are so many

1017.70.text:
they become strong in their broken places,
so strong sometimes that they can go back

1027.62.text: That's why I went to work for PEP.

1028.66.text:
I realized in 22 years God and the people

1035.18.text:
to go out and impact these guys, to minster

1039.93.text: like me, and I love it.

1043.85.text:
I got out with a career opportunity for a

1052.45.text:
I bought a car a couple of months out and
I made wise choices with that because of what

1060.58.text:
I bought a car that was two years old, low

1066.88.text:
I've eliminated debt, I built my emergency

1072.17.text: frugally and not wasting my money anymore.

1075.02.text:
I joined a church, I joined an AA group, I'm

1080.39.text:
like Washington D.C. and speak and follow

1090.93.text:
It is amazing what happens when people invest

1095.83.text: So let me get to the ask part.

1101.12.text:
There are literally thousands of people that
are languishing in prison, broken, don't know

1108.67.text:
If they knew the way out, they wouldn't have

We would love to have you help us, pep.org,

PEP.org, but there are other great organizations

Matthew 25, Jesus used the parable of the

Our mission statement is, "We are servant

1161.64.text:

1172.28.text:
Amazing things happen, and I realized something

1177.20.text: I got strong in my broken places.

1180.87.text:
So let's go back to that question that the

1184.10.text: Today I would say, "Yes, your honor.

1185.97.text: I do have something to say.

1191.39.text:
I am sorry that I caused so much devastation,
pain, and suffering to so many.

1196.12.text:
I'm sorry that the victim of my crime can
never learn how to do an email and go pump

1202.06.text: gas and spend way too much time on Facebook.

1207.48.text:
I'm sorry that he will never give his daughter's
hand away in marriage.

1210.19.text:
I am sorry that he will never sit on the porch
with his wife in their golden years.

1214.69.text:
I'm sorry that I caused my mom and family
shame and embarrassment.

1220.10.text:
I'm sorry that I contributed to our community
in the fear that is involved that makes people

1225.27.text:
want to lock their door at night, and I'm
sorry that I have contributed to the drug

1232.63.text:
I promise to shoulder whatever responsibility
that takes.

1237.19.text:
I will embrace whatever punishment I've got
and I will use that time and not waste it,

1241.82.text:
and I will change and do something different
with that and I will try to balance the scales,

1246.01.text: although I know that I can't.

1250.48.text: But here's what I want you to know.

1252.66.text:
Please do not let me languish and drown in
my consequences.

1261.06.text:
I want to come up and do something different,
but I can't do it by myself.

1265.89.text:
Send me someone who has made a mistake, who
has been a failure, who knows what it's like

1270.97.text:
to let other people down, who has been ashamed
and knows what that's like to come and help

1279.08.text:
Send me someone that will help me get strong
